questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to the physician for a follow-up examination. He has a 3-month history of a nonproductive cough. He has been treated with diphenhydramine since his last visit 2 weeks ago, but his symptoms have persisted. He does not smoke. He drinks 3 beers on the weekends. He is 177 cm (5 ft 10 in) tall and weighs 76 kg (168 lb); BMI is 24 kg/m2. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Physical examination and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin therapy in a patient with a history of cough can be indicated to treat suspected pneumonia. While a dry, nonproductive cough can occur in cases of atypical pneumonia, this diagnosis is unlikely considering the patient's age, absence of extrapulmonary symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgias), and normal chest x-ray.

B) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic cough often receive empiric treatment for the most common underlying conditions, including upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and asthma. This patient's cough has persisted despite treatment with an antihistamine (diphenhydramine), making UACS unlikely. Since he has no symptoms suggestive of GERD (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation), cough-variant asthma is the most likely diagnosis. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is the first-line diagnostic step in patients with suspected obstructive lung disease. Spirometry showing an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation (postbronchodilator test) confirms the diagnosis of asthma. If PFT does not yield a definitive diagnosis, a bronchoprovocation test can be performed.

C) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole therapy in a patient with a persistent cough is indicated if gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is suspected. While the connection is not fully understood, chronic cough in individuals with GERD is thought to be caused by a protective reflex following aspiration of gastric acid into the respiratory tract. Since GERD is unlikely to present only with a cough and no other typical features (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation), this diagnosis is unlikely and another cause should first be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

A tuberculin skin test is used to screen at-risk individuals for asymptomatic latent tuberculosis. Risk factors for contracting tuberculosis include immunosuppression (e.g., HIV), malnutrition, living in prisons or homeless shelters, and being either native to or having traveled in an endemic area (e.g., India). This patient has no risk factors for contracting a tuberculosis infection.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are reserved for managing severe, treatment-refractory asthma. This patient has no symptoms of severe asthma (e.g., severe dyspnea, hypoxemia) and a diagnosis has not yet been established.

F) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the chest in a patient with a history of cough are indicated to detect malignancies, lung consolidations (e.g., in tuberculosis), bronchiectasis, and pneumonia. Since this patient has no signs of infection or symptoms suggestive of malignancy (e.g., hemoptysis) and his chest x-ray shows no abnormalities, a CT scan is not indicated.
questions.hint: A chronic cough that has not resolved with a trial of an antihistamine requires further evaluation to rule out airway diseases.

questions.text: A 22-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 12-week history of persistent cough. The cough is nonproductive and present throughout the day. She has not noticed an exacerbation of symptoms when lying down. She otherwise feels well. She has not had any changes in appetite or exercise tolerance. Use of herbal cough medications has not provided any symptom relief. She has no history of serious illness but reports getting a runny nose every morning during winter. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 68/min, respirations are 12/min, and blood pressure is 110/76 mm Hg. Oropharyngeal examination shows a cobblestone pattern in the posterior pharyngeal mucosa. Cardiopulmonary examination and an x-ray of the chest show no abnormalities. Her FEV1 is normal. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids (e.g., prednisone) are used to treat severe persistent asthma and acute exacerbation of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The patient has no classic symptoms associated with obstructive airway disease (e.g., wheezing, dyspnea), and her FEV1, which would be reduced in obstructive airway disease, is normal. Intranasal corticosteroids (e.g., fluticasone, budesonide) can be considered in patients with treatment-refractory UACS.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhaled long-acting beta-2 agonists (e.g., salmeterol) are used to treat chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and persistent asthma. This patient has no classic symptoms of obstructive airway disease (e.g., wheezing, dyspnea), and her FEV1, which would be reduced in obstructive airway disease, is normal. Cough-variant asthma cannot be excluded with certainty but UACS is a much more frequent cause of chronic cough and runny nose.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton-pump inhibitors (PPIs) such as pantoprazole are used to treat gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), which can manifest with chronic nonproductive cough. However, a chronic cough due to GERD would be worse at night and in the supine position. Moreover, this patient does not have strong risk factors for GERD (e.g., heavy smoking, obesity) or other symptoms of GERD (e.g., heartburn, reflux). A different treatment is indicated for this patient before a trial of PPIs is considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Codeine is an opioid used as a central cough suppressant for symptomatic relief, but it is not the most appropriate next step in management for this patient. In UACS, in which cough serves as a protective mechanism to prevent pooling of secretions, central cough suppression with codeine could increase the probability of secondary infections. Furthermore, evidence suggests that use of codeine does not have any added benefits over placebo.

E) INCORRECT:

Patients who produce thick sputum (e.g., due to cystic fibrosis or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease) may benefit from administration of oral acetylcysteine as an adjunct mucolytic therapy. However, this patient does not have a productive cough, nor does she have symptoms of obstructive airway disease (e.g., wheezing, dyspnea).

F) CORRECT:

Patients with suspected UACS should receive empiric treatment with a first-generation antihistamine (e.g., dimetindene, diphenhydramine) for 2 weeks to achieve decongestion and subsequent reduction of postnasal drip. If symptoms improve within these 2 weeks, the diagnosis of UACS is confirmed. The underlying cause of UACS (e.g., allergic rhinitis, nonallergic rhinitis, chronic rhinosinusitis) should be subsequently treated.
questions.hint: Chronic cough (> 8 weeks), a history of rhinitis, evidence of a postnasal drip (e.g., cobblestone mucosa in the posterior pharynx), and no features of lower respiratory involvement (e.g., dyspnea, crackles, stridor) are compatible with upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), the most common cause of chronic cough.

questions.text: A 57-year-old patient comes to the physician for a 2-month history of progressive dyspnea and cough productive of large amounts of yellow, blood-tinged sputum. He has a history of COPD and recurrent upper respiratory tract infections. Examination of the lung shows bilateral crackles and end-expiratory wheezing. An x-ray of the chest shows thin-walled cysts and tram-track opacities in both lungs. The physician prescribes nebulized N-acetylcysteine. Which of the following is the most likely effect of this drug?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

An increased ciliary beat rate enhances mucociliary clearance and is the mechanism of action of beta-agonists such as salmeterol, which can be used in severe cases of COPD (GOLD stage 4). NAC does not affect ciliary beat rate.

B) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of peptidoglycan crosslinking inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis and is the mechanism of action of beta-lactam antibiotics like penicillin. Antibiotics may be indicated in COPD exacerbations, but unlike NAC, penicillins are not mucolytic agents. NAC does not affect peptidoglycan crosslinking.

C) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of the vagus nerve (parasympathetic stimulation) increases mucous secretion, which helps to dislodge mucus plugs from the smaller airways during coughing. This is the mechanism of action of expectorants such as guaifenesin. NAC does not stimulate the vagus nerve or increase parasympathetic stimulation.

D) INCORRECT:

Inhibition of phosphodiesterase is the mechanism of action of long-acting phosphodiesterase 4 inhibitors like roflumilast, which can be used to reduce COPD exacerbations. NAC does not inhibit phosphodiesterase.

E) INCORRECT:

Reduction of mucus hypersecretion by blockage of parasympathetic stimulation is the mechanism of action of anticholinergic medications like ipratropium. Anticholinergic medications are mucoregulators, whereas acetylcysteine is a mucolytic agent.

F) CORRECT:

NAC reduces crosslinking within the mucous by breaking down disulfide bonds that form in mucous plugs, reducing them to sulfhydryl bonds. As a result, the mucus secretions have a lower viscosity, are more easily expectorated, and help to clear airways. On long-term use, nebulized NAC has been shown to reduce the number of COPD exacerbations. It also has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

G) INCORRECT:

Breakdown of leukocyte DNA by recombinant DNAses, such as dornase alpha, reduces mucous viscosity and increases its clearance (leucocyte DNA is highly viscous). While NAC also reduces mucous viscosity, it does not affect leukocyte DNA.

questions.text:
The response options for the next 2 items are the same. Select one answer for each item in the set.
For each patient with a cough, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 66-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic cough. She reports that the cough is nonproductive and worse when she lies down. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 25 years. She has hypertension and coronary artery disease. Current medications include losartan, aspirin, and pravastatin. Her temperature is 37.3°C (99.1°F), pulse is 84/min, respirations are 21/min, and blood pressure is 144/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 94%. Pulmonary examination shows mild bibasilar crackles. Cardiac examination shows an S3 gallop. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 88% and an FEV1 of 90%. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is decreased.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with emphysema can present with dry cough and decreased DLCO (due to alveolar destruction) on spirometry and cigarette smoking is a risk factor for emphysema. However, chest auscultation would disclose decreased breath sounds and/or wheezes (due to small airway collapse) rather than bibasilar crackles. Furthermore, spirometry would show decreased FEV1 and a decreased FEV1:FVC, indicating an obstructive lung disease.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) can manifest with a dry cough. However, patients with UACS would also display symptoms of rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, rhinorrhea), frequent throat clearing, and/or hoarseness. Furthermore, UACS does not affect the lower airway and therefore does not explain the crackles or spirometric findings in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) can manifest as a dry chronic cough with nocturnal exacerbation (due to the recumbent position during sleep) as a result of laryngeal irritation or aspiration of gastric contents into the lower airways. However, patients with GERD also present with a history of retrosternal burning pain, dysphagia, and regurgitation, which this patient does not have. Furthermore, GERD does not explain the bibasilar crackles, spirometric findings, and the S3 gallop in this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious pneumonia can manifest with a cough, crackles, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC), and decreased DLCO. However, the protracted onset of the patient's current symptoms and lack of any signs of infection (e.g., fever) makes an infectious etiology highly unlikely. Furthermore, the crackles would be localized to the area(s) of pulmonary consolidation, and bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop would not be expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can manifest with a chronic dry cough, bibasilar crackles, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC), and decreased DLCO. However, this patient does not have a history of exposure to the antigens that trigger hypersensitivity pneumonitis (e.g., hay, mold, bird excreta). In addition, the presence of an S3 gallop and other cardiovascular risk factors in this patient makes a different diagnosis more likely.

F) INCORRECT:

Bronchial asthma can manifest with dry cough in patients with risk factors such as aspirin use and cigarette smoking. However, physical examination would show diffuse wheezes rather than bibasilar crackles. In addition, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC) and normal or increased DLCO would be expected. This patient's S3 gallop and other cardiovascular risk factors suggest another diagnosis.

G) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors, which are used to treat hypertension, can also cause a dry cough (due to decreased bradykinin breakdown). However, this patient's hypertension is being treated with losartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker, which is not typically associated with a cough. Moreover, a bradykinin-induced cough would not be associated with crackles, orthopnea, or a restrictive lung disease pattern on spirometry.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with a dry cough, bibasilar crackles, decreased DLCO, and spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC). Also, cigarette smoking is a significant risk factor for pulmonary fibrosis. However, the presence of an S3 gallop and other cardiovascular risk factors (e.g., coronary artery disease, hypertension) in this patient makes a different diagnosis more likely.

I) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer is an important differential diagnosis in this patient presenting with dry cough, particularly considering her history of smoking, which is a significant risk factor for developing lung cancer. However, bibasilar crackles and an S3 gallop would not be expected with lung cancer.

J) CORRECT:

Dry cough that is worse when lying down, fine inspiratory crackles at the lung bases, and an S3 gallop on auscultation in a patient with multiple risk factors (e.g., hypertension, smoking, coronary artery disease) suggest congestive heart failure. The spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (e.g., normal FEV1, normal FEV1:FVC) and decreased DLCOare due to cardiogenic pulmonary edema, which prevents full lung expansion and good gas exchange at the alveoli. Pulmonary edema usually indicates severe or decompensated heart failure, which will require aggressive diuresis (e.g., furosemide) to reduce volume overload.

K) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis can manifest with cough and crackles and cigarette smoking is a risk factor for this condition. However, the cough would be productive, and must be present for at least three months per year for two consecutive years before chronic bronchitis can be diagnosed. In addition, patients with chronic bronchitis would have spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC) and normal DLCO.

L) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis would manifest with a chronic cough and crackles. However, in patients with bronchiectasis, the cough would be productive and the crackles would manifest diffusely rather than at the lung bases. In addition, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., decreased FEV1, decreased FEV1:FVC) and normal DLCO would be expected.
questions.hint: This patient's cough is most likely to improve after administration of furosemide.

questions.text:
For each patient with a cough, select the most likely diagnosis.
A 68-year-old man comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of episodic cough. He reports that the cough is nonproductive and worse at night and when he walks to buy groceries. He has not had chest pain, hemoptysis, palpitations, or heartburn. He smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for 30 years but quit 8 years ago when his granddaughter was born. He has hypertension and osteoarthritis of the right hip. Current medications include hydrochlorothiazide and celecoxib. His temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 71/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 139/85 mm Hg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 97%. Pulmonary examination shows diffuse end-expiratory wheezing. Cardiac examination shows no murmurs, rubs, or gallops. Spirometry shows an FEV1:FVC ratio of 60% and an FEV1 of 65%. The diffusion capacity of the lung (DLCO) is normal.
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Emphysema can cause a chronic dry cough, end-expiratory wheezing (due to small airway collapse), and spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio) and a history of smoking is a significant risk factor for emphysema. However, emphysema results in a decreased DLCO whereas this patient's DLCO is normal. Furthermore, the onset of cough 8 years after complete smoking cessation makes a different diagnosis more likely.

B) INCORRECT:

Upper airway cough syndrome (UACS) can manifest with a chronic dry cough. However, UACS is associated with symptoms of rhinitis (e.g., sneezing, rhinorrhea), frequent throat clearing, and/or hoarseness, which are not seen here. In addition, UACS does not affect the lower airway and, therefore, does not explain the wheezing or spirometric findings in this patient.

C) INCORRECT:

Gastrointestinal reflux disease (GERD) can manifest as a dry chronic cough with nocturnal exacerbation (due to the recumbent position during sleep) as a result of laryngeal irritation or aspiration of gastric contents into the lower airways. However, patients with GERD typically present with a history of heartburn, which is not seen here. Furthermore, GERD does not explain the wheezing or spirometric findings in this patient, and it is not exacerbated by exercise (i.e., walking to buy groceries).

D) INCORRECT:

Infectious pneumonia can manifest with a cough. However, the protracted onset of this patient's current symptoms with no signs of infection (e.g., fever) makes an infectious etiology highly unlikely. Furthermore, chest auscultation in patients with infectious pneumonia typically reveals coarse inspiratory crackles rather than wheezes, and spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio) and decreased DLCO are expected, not the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio and normal DLCO seen here.

E) INCORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can manifest with a dry chronic cough. However, chest auscultation in patients with hypersensitivity pneumonitis typically reveals fine inspiratory crackles rather than wheezes. In addition, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio) and decreased DLCO are expected, not the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio and normal DLCO seen here. Furthermore, this patient does not have a history of exposure to the antigens that trigger hypersensitivity pneumonitis (e.g., hay, mold, bird excreta).

F) CORRECT:

Bronchial asthma, which is characterized by airway hyperresponsiveness and bronchial obstruction, can manifest at any age. In young patients, asthma is typically caused by a type I hypersensitivity to an allergen. In older patients, nonallergic pathologies (e.g., irritant inhalation, exertion, stress, medications, GERD) can also cause bronchial asthma. Clinical features of bronchial asthma include a chronic dry cough with nocturnal and exercise-induced exacerbation and diffuse end-expiratory wheezing. Spirometry shows features of obstructive lung disease, such as decreased FEV1 and decreased FEV1:FVC ratio. The airway obstruction in bronchial asthma characteristically worsens following a methacholine challenge test and improves following the inhalation of a bronchodilator (e.g., albuterol). Since alveolar gas exchange is not impaired in bronchial asthma, the DLCO is usually normal or can be slightly increased as a result of hyperinflation without alveolar destruction.

G) INCORRECT:

Aspirin and other COX-1 inhibiting NSAIDs can cause a pseudoallergic reaction known as aspirin-exacerbated respiratory disease (AERD), which can manifest with a chronic, dry cough and wheezing. However, additional clinical features, such as recurrent rhinosinusitis and nasal polyps, are expected. In addition, this patient is currently on celecoxib, a selective COX-2 inhibitor, which is usually tolerated in patients with AERD. Similarly, ACE inhibitors can result in a dry cough and wheezing, but this patient's hypertension is being treated with hydrochlorothiazide, which does not cause pulmonary side effects.

H) INCORRECT:

Pulmonary fibrosis can manifest with a dry cough and a past history of smoking is a significant risk factor for pulmonary fibrosis. However, chest auscultation in patients with pulmonary fibrosis typically reveals fine bibasilar inspiratory crackles rather than diffuse wheezes. In addition, spirometric findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio) and decreased DLCO are expected in patients with pulmonary fibrosis, not the decreased FEV1:FVC ratio and normal DLCO seen here.

I) INCORRECT:

Lung cancer can manifest with a cough and, in advanced stages, wheezing due to bronchial obstruction by the tumor. In addition, a history of smoking is a significant risk factor for lung cancer. However, the wheezes are typically localized to the site of bronchial obstruction, unlike the diffuse wheezes seen here, and other features of malignancy, such as weight loss, are expected.

J) INCORRECT:

Congestive heart failure (CHF) can manifest with a chronic cough and, occasionally, wheezing (i.e., cardiac asthma) with spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio). These findings, however, typically occur when patients with CHF develop acute decompensation. In CHF without acute decompensation, spirometry usually shows findings of restrictive lung disease (normal or increased FEV1:FVC ratio). In addition, patients with CHF typically have decreased rather than normal DLCO (due to pulmonary edema) as well as other clinical features, such as peripheral edema, jugular venous distention, and fine, inspiratory crackles.

K) INCORRECT:

Chronic bronchitis manifests with cough, wheezing, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio), and normal DLCO. However, the cough in chronic bronchitis is productive, unlike the nonproductive cough seen here, and the cough must have been present for at least 3 months per year in 2 consecutive years before chronic bronchitis can be diagnosed. In addition, chronic bronchitis is typically associated with active cigarette smoking whereas this patient quit smoking 8 years ago.

L) INCORRECT:

Bronchiectasis manifests with a chronic cough, spirometric findings of obstructive lung disease (e.g., ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1:FVC ratio), normal DLCO, and, occasionally, wheezing, all of which are consistent with this patient's presentation. However, in patients with bronchiectasis, the cough is typically productive, and chest auscultation would also reveal coarse crackles, which are not seen here.
questions.hint: This patient's FEV1:FVC ratio will most likely return to the normal range shortly after the administration of albuterol.

questions.text:
A 21-year-old man presents with a cough that began about 6 months ago, when he had a cold, and has persisted despite resolution of the other cold symptoms. The cough is worse with exercise and exposure to cold air, and it occasionally occurs at night, but the patient does not recall it awakening him from sleep recently.
His vital signs are unremarkable. On examination, he coughs when asked to take deep breaths, and a faint expiratory wheeze is present. His nasal mucosa and the rest of the physical examination are normal. Spirometry findings are normal.
Which one of the following treatments is most likely to be successful in treating this patient's cough?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Long-acting beta-agonists should only be used in conjunction with an inhaled glucocorticoid when treating asthma, because monotherapy with long-acting beta-agonists has been associated with a higher rate of respiratory failure and death in patients with asthma.

B) CORRECT:

Viral respiratory tract infections can lead to the development of asthma in adults who were previously asymptomatic, although the mechanism by which this happens is unknown. This patient’s persistent cough, a likely manifestation of airway hyperresponsiveness, started after a common cold. Normal results on spirometry testing do not rule out asthma, because patients can have significant symptoms and still maintain normal lung function.

According to the current Global Initiative for Asthma (GINA) guidelines, the preferred initial treatment is an as-needed low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler. A 2020 update from the National Asthma Education and Prevention Program (NAEPP) recommends beginning with a short-acting beta-agonist (SABA) if symptoms are intermittent; thus, as-needed albuterol would have been another acceptable option in this case. If an as-needed SABA alone is inadequate, then the NAEPP guidelines recommend stepping up to either an as-needed low-dose glucocorticoid-formoterol inhaler or a daily low-dose inhaled glucocorticoid.

See “Stepwise asthma treatment” table.

Key learning point: The most likely cause of a chronic cough that is exacerbated by cold air and exercise is asthma.

C) INCORRECT:

Although a leukotriene-receptor antagonist is also an alternative, it is not first-line therapy for asthma, and as-needed medications are preferred as a first step.

D) INCORRECT:

Guaifenesin, which would treat the symptom of cough but not the underlying cause, is not recommended.

E) INCORRECT:

Postnasal drip is a common cause of chronic cough, and a nasal glucocorticoid would be a good choice to treat allergic rhinitis; however, the presence of exercise- and cold-induced cough with the wheeze on examination makes asthma a more likely etiology for this patient’s cough.

questions.text:
A 43-year-old man with a history of diabetes and hypertension presents with progressive cough and dyspnea on exertion for the past 6 months. He notes that the cough occasionally produces clear sputum and is accompanied by intermittent wheezing. He has no history of obstructive lung disease, but for the past 6 months, he has been treated for a presumptive diagnosis of asthma with a medium-dose inhaled glucocorticoid, an oral leukotriene receptor antagonist, and an as-needed short-acting bronchodilator. He has also been treated with multiple courses of oral antibiotics. None of these treatments have improved his symptoms. He has not experienced weight loss, night sweats, or recent travel and has never smoked.
The patient is currently afebrile, with a heart rate of 76 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 147/89 mm Hg, a respiratory rate of 16 breaths per minute, and an oxygen saturation of 98% while he breathes ambient air. Examination of the nares is unremarkable; oropharyngeal examination reveals no lesions, and when the patient protrudes his tongue, both the uvula and the tonsillar pillars are visible. Cardiac examination shows a regular rhythm with no murmurs and no jugular venous distention. Lung examination reveals right-sided wheezing with forced expiration and vesicular breath sounds on the left. There is no pedal edema.
A chest radiograph shows no acute cardiopulmonary disease, and a CT scan of the chest is unremarkable. Screening pulmonary function tests are normal.
Which one of the following tests is most likely to provide a diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

This patient is most likely suffering from an endobronchial obstruction in the airways of the right lung and should undergo a bronchoscopy for inspection of the airways.

Asthma and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease are the most common causes of wheezing. However, in a patient who has not responded to bronchodilator therapy, additional causes of wheezing should be considered, particularly additional anatomic or functional causes of airway obstruction.

A variety of conditions can cause obstruction of the airway and result in wheezing or, in the case of the upper airway, stridor. Central airway obstruction may be caused by malignancy (primary lung cancer or a metastatic lesion) or by nonmalignant causes, including infiltrative, inflammatory, and infectious diseases. Airway inspection with the bronchoscope may also detect tracheobronchomalacia or excessive dynamic airway collapse. On rare occasions, a foreign body (e.g., peanut, tooth) is found in an airway, causing focal obstruction.

Wheezing is the effect of airflow through a narrowed orifice; however, the location of wheezing heard on examination may not always correlate to the exact anatomic location of obstruction. Bronchoscopy is the test of choice for airway inspection and may also allow for biopsy of lesions or removal of foreign bodies visualized in the airway.

Key learning point: Wheezing, particularly unilateral wheezing, that is not responsive to typical therapies for obstructive lung disease should raise concern for an endobronchial lesion resulting in airway obstruction.

B) INCORRECT:

An echocardiogram may detect cardiac dysfunction or signs of volume overload, which can lead to pulmonary edema and wheezing on examination. However, the wheezing would not be expected to be unilateral in the setting of pulmonary edema or cardiac dysfunction, and the patient has no other physical examination findings to raise concern for these diagnoses.

C) INCORRECT:

Tuberculosis may cause webs or lymphadenopathy, which can result in airway obstruction and manifest with hemoptysis. However, this patient has no risk factors for tuberculosis, and with unilateral wheezing on examination, the patient should be evaluated for an endobronchial mass. Therefore, sputum culture with acid-fast stain is not the most appropriate next step.

D) INCORRECT:

Methacholine challenge testing can aid in the assessment of suspected asthma; however, this patient’s complete lack of response to asthma therapy and the unilateral nature of his wheezing make asthma an unlikely diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Flexible laryngoscopy can sometimes be used by to diagnose paradoxical vocal-fold motion (also called vocal-cord dysfunction). This condition, in which the vocal folds and cords move in such a way as to cause transient wheezing or stridor, is poorly understood but may lead to recurrent episodes of dyspnea and wheezing or stridor. However, it would not cause unilateral lung symptoms.

questions.text:
Patient Information
Age: 43 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office
History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: “I'm worried about this cough lasting for so long.”
History of Present Illness:

9-month history of progressively worsening cough

sodium chloride inhalation and air humidification has not improved symptoms
increasingly short of breath with mild exercise; needs to take several breaks when cleaning out the horse stable

Past Medical History:


4 episodes of urinary tract infections over the past 12 months; treated with trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin
atopic dermatitis that is well controlled with moisturizing agents

Medications:
none
Vaccinations:
up-to-date
Allergies:
no known drug allergies
Family History:
noncontributory 
Psychosocial History:

lives with husband and daughter

started a new job as a groom in a horse stable 1 year ago
previously worked as a gardener
has smoked one-half pack of cigarettes daily for 7 years

does not drink alcoholic beverages or use other substances

Physical Examination


Temp
Pulse
Resp
BP
O2 Sat
Ht
Wt
BMI


36.6°C(97.9°F)
96/min
20/min
110/70 mm Hg
96% on RA
168 cm(5 ft 6 in)
56 kg(124 lb)
19.8 kg/m2




Appearance: sitting in chair; not in acute distress
Skin: no rashes
HEENT: normal conjunctivae and oropharynx; PERRLA; thyroid gland is normal in size with no mass or tenderness
Pulmonary: bilateral diffuse crackles

Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2; no murmurs, rubs, or gallops
Abdominal: nondistended; normoactive bowel sounds; soft, nontender
Extremities: no edemas; no digital clubbing 
Neurologic: fully oriented; cranial nerves grossly intact; no focal deficits

Diagnostic Studies

pulmonary function testing: FEV1 76% of predicted; FVC 74% of predicted; FEV1/FVC ratio of 0.95; DLCO decreased

chest x-ray: diffuse increase in reticular opacities



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease is associated with a history of smoking and may manifest with dyspnea, chronic cough, and decreased DLCO. However, PFTs would reveal an obstructive lung disease pattern with a decreased FEV1/FVC ratio, while chest x-rays usually show signs of pulmonary hyperinflation rather than fibrotic changes.

B) INCORRECT:

Medication-induced lung injury may manifest with dyspnea, fatigue, cough, PFTs showing a restrictive pattern with decreased DLCO, and fibrotic changes on chest x-ray. Several medications potentially induce lung injury, including nitrofurantoin, amiodarone, and certain chemotherapeutic agents such as bleomycin, busulfan, and methotrexate. Medication-induced lung injury is not an adverse effect of trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole and fosfomycin.

C) INCORRECT:

Chronic pulmonary aspergillosis can be caused by hay containing Aspergillus spores and may manifest with chronic cough, shortness of breath, and fibrotic changes on chest x-ray. However, it primarily affects immunocompromised individuals and individuals with previous pulmonary pathologies such as tuberculosis. Symptoms frequently include hemoptysis and recurrent acute pneumonia due to superinfections. Chest x-rays commonly show cavities or aspergillomas adjacent to areas of fibrosis.

D) CORRECT:

Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) is a combined type III and type IV hypersensitivity reaction caused by inhalation of organic particles, such as animal proteins, microorganisms (e.g., actinomycete spores from moldy hay), and inorganic chemicals (see “Overview of antigens and diseases in hypersensitivity pneumonitis” table). HP is often a result of occupational exposure to these antigens and is a notifiable occupational disease. HP can be acute, manifesting within 12 hours of exposure with flu-like symptoms, dyspnea, and chest tightness; or chronic, manifesting after weeks to years of exposure with progressive dyspnea, cough, fatigue, and weight loss. The diagnosis of HP is based on a history of antigen exposure, typical clinical and radiological features, and supportive diagnostic studies. PFTs typically show findings of ILD.

A high-resolution CT should be obtained in all patients to classify HP as fibrotic or nonfibrotic, which impacts further workup, treatment, and prognosis. The cornerstone of HP management is antigen avoidance.

E) INCORRECT:

Allergic asthma is triggered by allergens such as mold spores, which may be found in hay. It is also associated with atopic dermatitis and typically manifests with cough and dyspnea. However, PFTs in allergic asthma show obstructive lung disease pattern with a reduced FEV1/FVC ratio and normal or increased DLCO. Imaging is not routinely recommended for allergic asthma, but chest x-rays are usually normal or may show pulmonary hyperinflation and bronchial wall thickening. Additionally, physical examination is likely to reveal end-expiratory wheezes rather than diffuse crackles.
questions.hint: This patient's restrictive lung disease pattern with decreased DLCO in pulmonary function testing (PFTs) and chest x-ray findings are consistent with interstitial lung disease (ILD). A detailed exposure history is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man comes to your clinic for follow-up. He has had a nonproductive cough for 3 months. He was treated with diphenhydramine after his last visit 2 weeks ago, but his symptoms have persisted. He does not smoke and drinks 3 beers on weekends. He is 177 cm tall and weighs 76 kg; BMI is 24. His temperature is 37.1°C, pulse is 78/min, respirations are 14/min, and blood pressure is 130/80 mm Hg. Oxygen saturation on room air is 97%. Physical examination and chest x-ray are normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Omeprazole therapy in a patient with a persistent cough is indicated if gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is suspected. While the connection is not fully understood, chronic cough in individuals with GERD is thought to be caused by a protective reflex following aspiration of gastric acid into the respiratory tract. Since GERD is unlikely to present only with a cough and no other typical features (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation), this diagnosis is unlikely and another cause should first be considered.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral corticosteroids are reserved for managing severe, treatment-refractory asthma. This patient has no symptoms of severe asthma (e.g., severe dyspnea, hypoxemia) and a diagnosis has not yet been established.

C) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin therapy in a patient with a history of cough can be indicated to treat suspected pneumonia. While a dry, nonproductive cough can occur in cases of atypical pneumonia, this diagnosis is unlikely considering the patient's age, absence of extrapulmonary symptoms (e.g., fever, fatigue, myalgias), and normal chest x-ray.

D) INCORRECT:

CT scan of the chest in a patient with a history of cough are indicated to detect malignancies, lung consolidations (e.g., in tuberculosis), bronchiectasis, and pneumonia. Since this patient has no signs of infection or symptoms suggestive of malignancy (e.g., hemoptysis) and his chest x-ray shows no abnormalities, a CT scan is not indicated.

E) CORRECT:

Patients with chronic cough often receive empiric treatment for the most common underlying conditions, including upper airway cough syndrome (UACS), gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD), and asthma. This patient's cough has persisted despite treatment with an antihistamine (diphenhydramine), making UACS unlikely. Since he has no symptoms suggestive of GERD (e.g., retrosternal burning pain, regurgitation), cough-variant asthma is the most likely diagnosis. Pulmonary function testing (PFT) is the first-line diagnostic step in patients with suspected obstructive lung disease. Spirometry showing an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) that reverses with bronchodilation (postbronchodilator test) confirms the diagnosis of asthma. If PFT does not yield a definitive diagnosis, a bronchoprovocation test can be performed.

Key learning point: Pulmonary function testing is the first-line diagnostic step for chronic cough unresponsive to antihistamines, especially when cough-variant asthma is suspected and initial evaluation is unrevealing.
questions.hint: A chronic cough that has not resolved with a trial of an antihistamine requires further evaluation to rule out airway diseases.

questions.text: A 32-year-old health care worker presents with a 4-day history of persistent cough and mild chest discomfort. The cough is initially dry but has become productive of clear sputum. She reports mild fatigue and occasional wheezing. Vital signs are BP, 118/72; P, 82; R, 16; T, 37.1°C (98.8°F); oxygen saturation, 99% on room air. Physical examination shows clear lung fields bilaterally with scattered rhonchi and mild expiratory wheezing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient's presentation is classic for acute bronchitis: productive cough in a healthy adult with normal vital signs (particularly afebrile), clear lung fields bilaterally, and scattered rhonchi with mild wheezing. The absence of focal examination findings (no crackles, diminished breath sounds, or dullness to percussion) and normal vital signs distinguishes this from pneumonia. Lower respiratory tract involvement (productive cough, chest discomfort, rhonchi) distinguishes bronchitis from an isolated upper respiratory tract infection.

B) INCORRECT:

Pneumonia typically manifests with fever and abnormal vital signs, along with focal examination findings such as crackles, diminished breath sounds, dullness to percussion, and/or asymmetrical findings. This patient is afebrile with normal vital signs and has clear lung fields bilaterally with only scattered rhonchi, making pneumonia unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

While this patient has wheezing, asthma exacerbations typically manifest with predominant dyspnea and widespread wheezing. Acute onset with productive cough and recent upper respiratory symptoms is more consistent with acute bronchitis. Additionally, there is no history suggesting underlying asthma, and this patient's wheezing is described as mild and scattered rather than the prominent, diffuse wheezing typical of asthma.

D) INCORRECT:

An isolated upper respiratory tract infection typically involves only the nose, throat, and sinuses. This patient's productive cough, chest discomfort, and lower respiratory tract findings (rhonchi and wheezing) indicate involvement of the bronchi and lower airways, which is characteristic of another diagnosis.

E) INCORRECT:

Atypical pneumonia can manifest with more subtle findings than typical bacterial pneumonia, but patients usually have systemic symptoms such as headache, myalgias, and malaise that are more prominent than seen in this patient. Additionally, even atypical pneumonia often manifests with some degree of fever and abnormal vital signs. This patient's normal vital signs, clear lung examination, and mild, localized symptoms are more consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with a 3-week history of productive cough. She has a history of hypertension and takes lisinopril. She reports mild dyspnea on exertion and has noticed her clothes fitting more loosely recently. Physical examination shows diminished breath sounds at the right base with dullness to percussion. Vital signs are BP, 142/88; P, 92; R, 14; T, 37.2°C (99.0°F); oxygen saturation, 94% on room air. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Discontinue lisinopril and reassess in 2 weeks

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Empiric antibiotic therapy is not appropriate without first obtaining imaging to confirm the diagnosis. While pneumonia is possible, the patient lacks fever and has other concerning features that require diagnostic evaluation to guide management.

B) INCORRECT:

Sputum culture may be useful but is not the immediate priority. The patient's red flags (i.e., abnormal physical examination findings and weight loss) require urgent evaluation to identify the underlying cause before microbiological studies are pursued.

C) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient presents with red flags for cough, including weight loss (clothes fitting loosely) and abnormal physical examination findings (diminished breath sounds and dullness to percussion). Additionally, mild hypoxemia is present. These findings warrant immediate chest x-ray to evaluate for underlying pathology such as pneumonia, pleural effusion, or malignancy before initiating treatment.

D) INCORRECT:

While angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors can cause chronic cough, this patient has red flags (i.e., weight loss, abnormal physical examination findings) that require immediate diagnostic evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Bronchodilator therapy is not indicated without evidence of bronchospasm or obstructive lung disease. This patient's presentation with weight loss and abnormal physical examination findings suggests a structural abnormality.

questions.text: A 42-year-old woman presents with a persistent dry cough that began 3 months ago. She was previously treated empirically for suspected upper airway cough syndrome without improvement. She reports occasional nighttime awakening due to cough but denies fever, weight loss, or hemoptysis. She has a 20 pack-year smoking history but quit 2 years ago. Vital signs are normal, and lung examination is clear. What is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Trial of proton pump inhibitor therapy

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Correct -- This patient has chronic cough (> 8 weeks) and failed empirical treatment for upper airway cough syndrome. Chest x-ray is indicated for all patients with chronic cough to exclude serious underlying pathology before proceeding with further sequential diagnostics or empirical treatments. This patient's smoking history further supports the need for imaging to evaluate for malignancy or other structural abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Spirometry with bronchial challenge testing is appropriate for suspected asthma evaluation in chronic cough, but another step is indicated first as part of the routine workup. This patient lacks typical asthma symptoms such as exercise-induced cough or wheezing.

C) INCORRECT:

Proton pump inhibitor therapy for suspected gastroesophageal reflux disease is part of sequential empirical treatment for chronic cough, but another step should be performed first to exclude structural abnormalities, especially in a patient with a 20 pack-year smoking history.

D) INCORRECT:

Nasopharyngeal PCR testing for atypical pathogens like pertussis could be considered based on this patient's preceding respiratory infection, but another step is needed first for chronic cough evaluation.

E) INCORRECT:

Referral to pulmonology might be appropriate in a patient with failed empirical treatment and 20 pack-year smoking history, but another step is indicated first as part of the standard evaluation for chronic cough before specialist referral.
